[SYNTAX]: Complex sentence structures may impede smooth reading for some readers.
[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary (e.g., "thou", "thee") might require additional effort for modern readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from historical narrative to the author's commentary on modern pilgrims.
[CLARITY]: Assumed knowledge of historical figures/events (e.g., Thomas Becket, Henry VIII) without brief context.

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "the imminence of further change carries with it no danger of any break in this long association"
[LEXICON]: Overly formal language may impede smooth reading for some audiences (e.g., "sultifying authority", "sultry atmosphere")
[PUNCTUATION]: Lack of clarity in long sentences (e.g., the final paragraph before St. Martin's discussion)

[LOGIC]: Abrupt transition from discussing Canterbury's Christian history to speculating about the future of the State Church
[STRUCTURE]: Non-chronological jump in discussing St. Martin's church history without clear connection to preceding paragraphs
[CLARITY]: Ambiguity in the resolution regarding St. Martin's church origins (could be clarified with a transitional sentence)
